Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2015 07:07PM snorkeler wrote: My oncologist checks my vitamin D level once a year, even though she does other blood tests every six months. She said the vitamin D level changes slowly. When first diagnosed I was at 11. Now 3+ years later, I'm at around 38. My oncologist thinks that as long as I'm in the 30s, I'm fine. However, my breast surgeon feels that I have room to go higher, so there is a difference of opinion. I've been taking 2000IUs daily for a long time now.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2013 08:39AM snorkeler wrote: I've had this done every time I've gotten a mammogram on my lumpectomy side. I think the tech said that they do this for the first 3 years after surgery.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy scar and mammo question.... cindee56 snorkeler

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2013 09:04AM snorkeler wrote: The way I got through the all the tests and waiting was to keep telling myself that the sooner I can figure out what the lump is, the sooner I can take care of it, whatever the case may be. And the biopsy is the only way to know for sure. Regardless of what the doctors think it is, I would want a biopsy for my own peace of mind. While driving to appointments and in the waiting room, I tried to breathe deeply and meditate and remember all the things I am thankful for (I even made a list on my phone so I could look at it whenever). And seeing all the other women waiting for their appointments made me realize that whatever the outcome, I won't be the only one. Things have come a long way since your father's mother's time, and each woman's situation is different anyway. And the bottom line is you're taking charge of your health--that can only be good for you and your family. I wish you the best.
Posts.Title: Core Needle Biopsy tomorrow and trying not to panic scarlettm512 bearcub

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2015 06:02PM snorkeler wrote: My tumor was right under the areola. The surgeon explained the lumpectomy this way: imagine a pie, taking out a slice, and then closing the pie up again. She had to take a little part of the nipple, and being small breasted, I was expecting a more noticeable disfigurement. But symmetry is excellent, and I still have full sensation. A lot of it is the skill of the surgeon and just plain luck. If she didn't get clean margins, she told me the second surgery would be a mastectomy. Best of luck with your treatment.
Posts.Title: difficult decisions- types of BMX surgery, experiences tshire MsVeryDenseBreasts

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2015 10:39AM snorkeler wrote: In my case, the surgeon ordered two pre-op MRIs: a breast MRI to see if there were any other cancerous areas in addition to the one confirmed IDC, and a chest MRI to check lymph nodes and for any signs of mets. In addition to reporting on breasts and lymph nodes (axillary, supra- and infraclavicular, and internal mammary), the radiologist also reported on my skin, bones, marrow, lungs, adrenals, and the top part of my liver (I am on the shorter side, so more of my body fit into the machine). When I entered the operating room for my lumpectomy, the surgeon was on the computer looking at the MRI images. I remember reading somewhere that breast ducts are too small to be seen with the naked eye. It turns out that in addition to the 1cm IDC, I had 2cm of DCIS, and the surgeon was able to get it all with wide margins. If she hadn't, then I would have had to then have a mastectomy. MRI does have limitations, as I found out first hand when after surgery it was discovered that one of my sentinel nodes had a micromet (1.5mm) that was too small to show up on the MRI (sensitive starting at 4-5mm). Since you are having chemo first, your tumor will probably shrink, maybe (hopefully!) completely, so that's probably why no one has ordered an MRI for now.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed, no MRI? NewDay123 NewDay123

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2016 07:59AM snorkeler wrote: It might have been there last year, just too small to be picked up by MRI. I had a sebaceous cyst show up one year, and in the report the radiologist referred back to the MRI from the year before, which did show something but it was very small. I do wonder about the first radiologist not mentioning anything in his report. Maybe it was not clear at that time that there was something there, because it was so small.
Posts.Title: Suspicious mass found on annual MRI, biopsy tomorrow Heyu snorkeler

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2015 09:00AM snorkeler wrote: Where I had radiation they called it active breathing control. At the first simulation, my RO determined that I would benefit from doing this, so there was another simulation with the breathing apparatus. As it was explained to me, when you take a deep breath, your chest expands, thereby increasing the distance from your heart to the surface getting radiated (your heart is now farther away). During the actual treatments, the techs measured how deeply I breathed, and if I didn't hit a certain level as determined in the simulation, they wouldn't turn on the radiation. It's only been 2+ years since treatment, so I can't really say if it helped, but so far I haven't had any heart issues.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2015 07:07PM snorkeler wrote: That's what happened to me. Ultrasound and MRI showed clear nodes, but then after surgery one of my sentinel nodes had a micromet of 1.5mm. MRI can pick up things starting at 4-5mm in size; I'm not sure about ultrasound.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2015 06:05AM snorkeler wrote: The literature from the imaging center I go to says that MRI is sensitive starting at 4-5mm, which explains why the pre-op MRIs I had (breast and chest, with and without contrast) missed the 1.5mm micromet in one of my sentinel nodes.
Posts.Title: Has anyone had an MRI miss their cancer? oceangirl654 lulu2533

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2014 08:28AM snorkeler wrote: I had a sebaceous cyst form from a blackhead/clogged pore, so it looked kind of like a pimple although it wasn't red. It showed up on my annual breast MRI as a probable sebaceous cyst, and when my breast surgeon looked at it she could tell that's what it was, maybe because it was close to the surface of the skin. She said it's not a problem unless it gets infected, and of course right after I saw her it got infected. It got bigger and red and tender. She couldn't remove it until the infection went down, so I had to wait a few weeks for the procedure. I was given antibiotics and also told to try hot compresses on it, and it did get smaller. After the procedure I was told to watch out for signs of infection which included "red streakiness." Even though the surgeon was sure it was a cyst, they send everything to pathology and the final pathology report confirmed sebaceous cyst with no malignancy found. It's good that you had a mammo and ultrasound, but like mjm1 I would also recommend that you have a doctor look at it, especially since it could be an infection.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2014 11:52AM snorkeler wrote: As I understand it, during acupuncture the needles are not supposed to break through the skin. A no-needle alternative would be acupressure. The same points on the body are used, but just by pressing with a finger. I've had success with treating constipation this way. I've never gone to a practitioner; I researched in books and tried it on myself. The most useful book I've found is called Acupressure's Potent Points. It's a self-care guide.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2014 07:24PM snorkeler wrote: Calendula cream was recommended to me by the rad onc nurses, but I think the ointment version would have been better. Towards the end of rads I got a tiny spot of peeling, so I started putting Aquaphor on top of the calendula cream. My skin got quite red, but the peeling didn't get any worse. Good luck!
Posts.Title: What ointments work best?? is Nozema a no-no? Notbuyingit Moderators

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2013 10:55PM snorkeler wrote: In my case, I freelance from home, so it was easier keeping things private which was my preference. Like kap, I think your course of treatment does determine things somewhat. My lumpectomy was an outpatient procedure and I didn't end up needing to do chemo, so there weren't problems during recovery and no visible effects of treatment to explain. One of my closest friends just became a doctor, and even though she lives across the country we talked almost every day during my treatment. Having support is important, but I wouldn't want everyone I run into constantly asking me how I'm feeling, etc., especially if they haven't been through it themselves. That's just me; the bottom line is that you decide who you want to tell or not tell. It's good that you're taking the time to think about it, because once you tell someone, you can't take it back, so hopefully they will react well and be helpful.
Posts.Title: how many people will I tell about the cancer? kpr msphil

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2015 01:37AM snorkeler wrote: My lymph node had a micromet of 1.5mm. To count as a positive node, there needs to be at least 2mm of cancer, so my situation is called clinically negative. However, cancer cells did make it to that node, so my oncologist ordered the Oncotype test to see if I should have chemo. The test came back low, so no chemo for me. I went on to radiation and am now 3+ years into tamoxifen.
